newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan PM's environment role draws cynicism at home.
newsitem.headline: Japan PM's environment role draws cynicism at home.

text.p: Japan's bid to take on a global leadership role in efforts to control greenhouse gases has been met with cynicism among environmental groups back home.

"I have doubts whether Japan can really become a leader in these issues," said Yurika Ayukawa of the Japan branch of the World Wide Fund for Nature. "It can't even set its own target to reduce carbon dioxide emissions."

On Monday, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto sought to play the role of mediator in setting targets for cutting heat-trapping pollution and pledged to make a success of a global warming conference in the western Japan city of Kyoto in December.

Hashimoto, in a speech at the "Earth Summit Plus Five" at the United Nations, also proposed medium-term measures such as offering environment-related foreign aid and exchanging technology information with other nations.

But Japan failed to propose its own numerical target to curb greenhouse gases, which will be the key theme in Kyoto and was a topic of hot debate at last week's Denver summit of the Group of Seven industrialised countries.
Instead, Hashimoto hailed the Denver summit communique, which said the participants wanted "meaningful, realistic and equitable" targets for curbing greenhouse gases by 2010.
"Japan only appears to be trying to please the United States," Ayukawa said.
The European Union proposed a 15 percent reduction in emissions below the 1990 level, to be achieved by 2010.
But the United States, which accounts for nearly one-fourth of all emitted greenhouse gases, rejected European demands to set specific targets.

Japan accounts for roughly five percent of the world's greenhouse gases, and the nation's carbon dioxide emissions climbed to a record high of 332 million tonnes in fiscal 1995, an 8.3 percent increase from 1990.
"Hashimoto's speech was all rhetoric and no content. He sounds more like a mouthpiece of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI)," said Yasuko Matsumoto of Greenpeace Japan.
Japan's powerful MITI and the industries it represents have been reluctant to consider strong measures to curb carbon dioxide emissions, such as setting targets and implementing "environment taxes".
"Hashimoto is talking only about vague medium- and long-term projects. Merely promising to start reduction by 2010 is too late," Matsumoto said.
Environment groups have targeted Japan on a host of other issues for its reluctance to put the environment before economic interests.

Japan's ambitious nuclear policy has suffered a setback after a cover-up of events that caused an explosion at a nuclear fuel reprocessing plant in March in Tokaimura, just 120 km (75 miles) from Tokyo.
The accident exposed 37 workers to low levels of radiation and was Japan's worst nuclear accident.
Rare coral reefs in southern Japan face destruction because of a government project to build an airport on the island of Ishikagijima in the East China Sea.
In April, authorities closed off the country's largest tidal wetland at Isahaya Bay in Kyushu, southern Japan, as part of a public works project.
In light of this, Matsumoto of Greenpeace doubted that Japan could persuade the Kyoto conference to agree on a numerical target for reducing greenhouse gases.

"The success of that meeting hinges on whether it can agree on specific measures to achieve early reduction of the gases. But Japan defines success as a condition where everyone is happy, which would be impossible for a conference like this," said Matsumoto.

Prime Minister Hashimoto has already indicated, in a meeting with Australian Prime Minister John Howard in April, that he "understood" Australia's position and pledged not to turn the Kyoto conference into a "forum of confrontation".
Australia relies heavily on coal and is against any target, saying it would cause economic damage.
"The Japanese style of trying to please everybody will not lead the Kyoto conference to success," Matsumoto said.
